definition: Pericles (c. 495-429 BC), Athenian strategist and politician before and at the start of the Peloponnesian war
father's elder brother/senior/paternal elder uncle/eldest of brothers/respectful form of address/Count, third of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]

li, ancient measure of length, approx. 500 m/neighborhood/ancient administrative unit of 25 families/(Tw) borough, administrative unit between the township 鎮|镇[zhen4] and neighborhood 鄰|邻[lin2] levels
abbr. for 克羅地亞|克罗地亚[Ke4 luo2 di4 ya4], Croatia/(Tw) abbr. for 克羅埃西亞|克罗埃西亚[Ke4 luo2 ai1 xi1 ya4], Croatia
Brutus (name)/Marcus Junius Brutus (85-42 BC), late Roman Republic politician who conspired against Julius Caesar/Lucius Junius Brutus (6th c. BC), founder of the Roman Republic
Thucydides (c. 455 - c. 400 BC), Greek historian, author of the History of the Peloponnesian War
Marcus Tullius Cicero (106-43 BC), famous Roman politician, orator and philosopher, murdered at the orders of Marc Anthony
Syracuse, Sicily/also written 錫拉庫薩|锡拉库萨[Xi1 la1 ku4 sa4]
Pisistratus (-528 BC), tyrant (ruler) of Athens at different times between 561 BC and 528 BC
Sophocles (496-406 BC), Greek tragedian, author of Oedipus the King
Socrates (469-399 BC), Greek philosopher/José Sócrates (1957-), prime minister of Portugal (2005-2011)
Richard the Lionheart (1157-1199), King Richard I of England 1189-1199

pinyin: Ya4 li4 shan1 da4 Da4 di4
